conclusion: To determine the pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K, we can use the information provided in the p-T graph.
The p-T graph shows a linear relationship between pressure (p) and temperature (T). The graph has two points: (200 K, 0.5 x 10^5 Pa) and (400 K, 1.0 x 10^5 Pa).

premise: The graph has two points: (200 K, 0.5 x 10^5 Pa) and (400 K, 1.0 x 10^5 Pa).
conclusion: The slope (m) of the line can be calculated using the formula: m = Δp/ΔT = (1.0 - 0.5) x 10^5 Pa / (400 - 200) K = 0.5 x 10^5 Pa / 200 K = 2.5 x 10^2 Pa/K.

premise: The slope is 2.5 x 10^2 Pa/K and using the point (200 K, 0.5 x 10^5 Pa).
conclusion: Using the point-slope form of the line equation p = mT + c, we find the y-intercept (c): 0.5 x 10^5 = 2.5 x 10^2 x 200 + c, c = 0. Therefore, the equation of the line is: p = 2.5 x 10^2 x T.

premise: Equation of the line is p = 2.5 x 10^2 x T.
conclusion: Substitute T = 600 K into the equation: p = 2.5 x 10^2 x 600 = 1.5 x 10^5 Pa.
